blog.description: I'm Lee Sherman, and Siryl is a black cat who doesn't exist. I share science fiction and fantasy paintings, and other works of art that make the fantastical and the hypothetical seem vividly real. This blog is always safe for work.  Links may not be.

tags: im available to write the script
summary:
The thing I want (hope, wish, pray) to see the most in Spider-Man: Far From Home is a
cameo.
Then we get Spider-Man: Home Is...
body:
The thing I want (hope, wish, pray) to see the most in Spider-Man: Far From Home is a

cameo.

Then we get Spider-Man: Home Is Where The Heart Is (or something witty like that).

Plot suggestion: Peter Parker goes up against his biggest villain yet (Doc Ock or Green Goblin), which leads to the birth of the Sinister Six (maybe Vulture makes a revenge comeback). He dies at the end of the film saving the city (similar to The Death of Spider-Man storyline).

(Or alternatively, Peter can’t be Spider-Man anymore for whatever reason so he mentors Miles like Tony (RIP!) mentored him.)

Post credits scene #1: we see Miles Morales at the funeral.

Post credits scene #2: we see Miles getting bit by a radioactive spider on his way home.

This sets up a new Spider-Man film series starring X (idk who’d be good) entitled The Ultimate Spider-Man.

blog.name: ironguardians
blog.title: tony stark defense squad
blog.description: kat - multifandom - stop forgetting about rhodey - bucky & sam are not sidekicks - prev. malfqy

summary: i'm equal parts excited and dreading ffh because. well. it's a spider-man movie! my baby boy! but there's also the fact that far...
body: i’m equal parts excited and dreading ffh because. well. it’s a spider-man movie! my baby boy! but there’s also the fact that far from home is going to show us the mcu without tony stark. sure, multiple previous mcu movies didn’t have him in them, but we knew he was alive. we knew tony stark was still living, even if the movie we were watching didn’t show us that. but now, starting with far from home, every reference to tony, every reference to iron man, and we’re reminded that he’s gone. our hero is gone. far from home is the start of an mcu where tony stark is absent. actually absent. i’ve been in denial since april 25th and when i go into the theater and watch this movie, i’ll have to see a world where he’s gone. and i’m not ready for that.

trail.content: i’m equal parts excited and dreading ffh because. well. it’s a spider-man movie! my baby boy! but there’s also the fact that far from home is going to show us the mcu without tony stark. sure, multiple previous mcu movies didn’t have him in them, but we knew he was alive. we knew tony stark was still living, even if the movie we were watching didn’t show us that. but now, starting with far from home, every reference to tony, every reference to iron man, and we’re reminded that he’s gone. our hero is gone. far from home is the start of an mcu where tony stark is absent. actually absent. i’ve been in denial since april 25th and when i go into the theater and watch this movie, i’ll have to see a world where he’s gone. and i’m not ready for that.

tags: also im not jewish myself so if i overstepped or said anything wrong please tell me!!
summary: i’m really disappointed in z and jacob batalon for the way they laughed at the possibility of a jewish spider-man. yes, i know...
body: i’m really disappointed in z and jacob batalon for the way they laughed at the possibility of a jewish spider-man. yes, i know that peter has only been heavily jewish coded in the comics so far and that nothing is outright confirmed on-panel, but it’s not far fetched for people to ask that question especially when his creator, stan lee, was jewish, and was played by andrew garfield, a jewish actor who said that his version of peter is jewish, and was voiced by two jewish actors, chris pine and jake johnson in into the spider-verse (and peter b. parker is canonically jewish, by the way, rewatch his wedding scene). misinformation isn’t the problem though, it’s just that they not only dismissed it really quickly, but also laughed at it like it was a funny joke.

reblog.comment: i’m really disappointed in z and jacob batalon for the way they laughed at the possibility of a jewish spider-man. yes, i know that peter has only been heavily jewish coded in the comics so far and that nothing is outright confirmed on-panel, but it’s not far fetched for people to ask that question especially when his creator, stan lee, was jewish, and was played by andrew garfield, a jewish actor who said that his version of peter is jewish, and was voiced by two jewish actors, chris pine and jake johnson in into the spider-verse (and peter b. parker is canonically jewish, by the way, rewatch his wedding scene). misinformation isn’t the problem though, it’s just that they not only dismissed it really quickly, but also laughed at it like it was a funny joke.
